text:
Hi. I'm Adrian DeLuca,
I hope you're enjoying re:Invent 2020.

On 'This My Architecture',
we love doing technical deep dives
in some of the most innovative companies

who are building in the cloud.
Last year I had the opportunity to go to Jakarta

and spend time with a really interesting
company called Halodoc.

They are literally changing
the way Health Care
is delivered to citizens of Indonesia.

Considering the global pandemic
gripping the world at the moment,

this kind of technology
is more important than ever.

In the special episode, I will tell you
about how I spent time with the engineering team,

where they showed me
how they were building the future of Telehealth,

one micro service at a time.
Let's take a look.

Every successful business
starts with a great idea.

Today, moving from concept to reality
is easier than ever before.

Join us, as we travel around the world
to meet developers, architects, and innovators,

to learn how they're building on the AWS Cloud.
Welcome, to 'This Is My Architecture'.
This is Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia.

Located in the northwest corner
of the most populated island in the world.

Rapid urbanization, coupled with competitive
investments and infrastructure
has made traffic pretty intense around here.

That means going to a hospital
can sometimes take hours.
And that's just the travel time.
Hospital queues can be so bad,

some people make a living
holding a place in line for others.

In Indonesia, there's only two doctors
for every 10,000  people.

it's no wonder most Indonesians only consider
going to the doctor when they're really sick.

So what if there was a way to see a doctor
without having to get onto these busy streets?

Let me show you. Hello Adrian,
so I'm Dr. Nisa, tell me how you feel today.

Well, Dr. Nisa, I was outside today,
it's quite a warm day,
and just outside... this is Halodoc.

A company and app that allows you to interact
with the doctor right from your phone.
So how is Halodoc good for your patients?

So, you know in Indonesia,
there are many people who live in rural areas.

And they have restricted access
to healthcare facilities.

Some will have to travel hours
to the nearest healthcare facilities.

So with Halodoc
you can just minimize the travel phase,

and then like in Jakarta you have
traffic jams all over the place, right,

so you don't have to travel,
and you got to reduce waiting time

to get to the healthcare facilities
and go to the doctor.

That's fantastic, thank you
so much doctor for helping me today.

Thank you Adrian, hope you get well soon.
Thank you.

An app that makes it possible
for a country of 264 million people
with 50% internet penetration

must have some serious technology behind it.
And now I'm going to find out how it works.

This is the nerve center at Halodoc,
where right now dozens of doctors
are fielding inquiries from all around the country.

As an island nation,
80% of calls are coming from outside the city,
where access is much more difficult.

And to learn about how all this works,
I'm joined by Abhilash,

the Chief Technology Officer for Halodoc.
Hi Abhilash, thanks for joining me today.
Thanks for having me.

So, I'm really keen to get underneath
the covers of the architecture,

but before we do that,
tell us a little bit about how it all started.

At Halodoc we started building
a tech stack about 3 years ago.
Our initial version was a simple monolith,

- one compute backed by simple database.
- Wow.

And, obviously things have changed
since then as you've continued to grow,
so walk us through some of those changes.

Since our inception, Halodoc
has started launching new business lines,

one of the business lines
is you can buy medicine online,

second business line
as you can talk to doctors online.

As soon when we started launching
new business lines,

it was obvious to us
that the monolith will not cut it.

And we have to go the micro service
route as soon as possible.

So it sounds like all these new interactions
that your users were having became
new microservices in your architecture.

Each microservice has a couple of
compute instances backed by persistence.

We use RDS, MySQL database,
so one group could be buying medicine online,

the second group could be talking
to a doctor online, and so on and so forth.

At the moment we have
40 to 50 microservices in production.

So you've gone from using a single class
of EC2 instance to having multiple different classes
based on user interactions.

Given that each of these microservices
have their own databases,

I'm keen to understand how you think
about data partitioning.

For certain use cases we had to ensure that
the data is consistent across different microservices.
A good example is users data.

As a user, you could buy
medicine, or talk to a doctor,

as these belongs to different microservices.
So what we did is we used DynamoDB,
to save all of our user data.

So I imagine all of these services
would use identity quite often,
so having a low latency database,

and being able to share that across
all these microservices is a big benefit.
Yep.

So I see another service there,
the Simple Notification Service,

something that we see quite often
in microservices architecture,
how are you using it?
So when we started our microservice journey,

I believe it was when we had about
10 microservices on production,

we started noticing that we were having unnecessary
tight coupling between our microservices.

One micro service would know
about the other micro service,
and would do a sync call, right.

So we wanted to kind of avoid that
and bring into a synchronized flexibility,

so we essentially decided to build an even bus,
and that's where the SNS journey started.

Now, you've obviously gone from
a virtual machine microservices but I see

you've gone even further and you're using
serverless Technologies so I'm keen to understand

- what is Lambda doing over here?
- Let's take an example.

Let's say you spoke to a doctor, and the doctor
issued an electronic prescription to you, right.

So the consultation service would raise an event
into SNS and SNS would trigger the Lambda.

Right, so you're using Lambda to go and curate
some of the data and your event bus
but also to create some stuff here as well.
And then, the Lambda enriches the event raised.
It pulls medicine names, the doctor name,

the patient name, and then generates the PDF
which can be used by the patients to buy the medicine.

Fantastic.
Now, what is the second Lambda doing over here?

So, one of the business use cases
we had is real-time visibility
on how certain metrics are doing.
For example availability of a doctor,

how many consultations that doctor
is doing and so on and so forth,
that was a requirement from the business side,

so the way that we solved it is that each
of these microservices would raise events.

It would go into SNS. From SNS
we would send it to Lambda,

Lambda would do the enriching
we spoke about earlier

and once the data is enriched
we could go into Kafka.
And on top of Kafka, we build Flink,

and then an Elasticsearch
and then a graph for final visualization.

Halodoc introduce
new business lines as microservices
to steadily decouple the business logic,

and tackle their monolith overtime.
That's actually a smart strategy.

We know in the cloud that services
are continuously evolving,
which means architecture never stops.

That means leveraging
new services and features that

continue to take away
undifferentiated heavy lifting,
can actually improve the applications over time.

Now, Abhilash talked about
using different classes of Amazon EC2
for each of the different microservices.

That allows him to match the right
compute and memory profiles
for different tasks in the application.

Over the past year, we've introduced a ton
of new features and options in Amazon EC2,

including 36% EBS optimize performance increases
with AWS Nitro based instances,

new graviton to powered instances like the C6G,
R6G and the M6G and for stateless microservices,

we improved EC2 spot with the ability
to provide rebalance recommendations,
and autoscale capacity rebalancing.

Halodocs architecture
is increasingly using AWS Lambda

not only to move away from managing servers
but also to reduce the cost of less active tasks.

This year for AWS Lambda,
we introduced latest support for

.Net and Java 8, CloudWatch insight
for a bit of troubleshooting and optimization,

and included it into the Compute Savings Plan
offering up to 17% cost reductions per year.

Now let's go back and learn
some more about the architecture.

The genius of Halodoc was emerging
of a network of doctors and pharmacists.

They connect 22,000 doctors and 1500 pharmacies
across 50 cities in Southeast Asia.
After a teleconference with the patient,

doctors upload the medical
prescriptions to the pharmacist

where they can be picked up and delivered.
Good morning.
Good morning.

So, Eliza, how has Halodoc
changed your pharmacy business?
So how was it easier for your patients?
That's great. So how does it all work?
So these are the GoJek drivers.

They're the ones that pick up
the medicine that patients need,
and deliver them right to their front door.

And Teddy over here is going
to show me just how it's done.
Let's go.

These Gojek are small, swift
and very maneuverable.

They can get potential life-saving
medicines to patient in under 40 minutes.
No wonder they're so popular.

And it's all part of a growing
sector of the economy, ride-sharing.

The other expanding sector
of the Indonesian economy is e-commerce.

Each has increased
by 60% over the last five years
and Halodoc is riding both those waves.

So, Abhilash, it's clear that Halodoc
really deals with a lot of data.
Not just in volume but also in type.

Let's start with what you do with the transactional data.
So from all the individual RDS's,

we are moving the data
into Redshift by using DMS.

- To the database migration service?
- Yes,

and on the Redshift
the business analyst can run queries

for monthly reports
or weekly reports and things like that.

- Fantastic, obviously very scalable data warehouse solution there.
- Yep.

Now, how do you keep
that RDS instance performing?

We want to ensure that
medical records are... saved,

we want to ensure that historical records is kept safe,
so the way we do it is from RDS,

all the data gets moved into Glacier.
For record-keeping.

There are major a lot of your analysts want to ask
questions about how the business is operating,

- tell me a little bit about how you helped them.
- Good question.

So, let's say I'm an analyst
who is responsible for ensuring that
there are enough doctors on the platform.

I want to know how many doctors
are on line at a given moment.

For this we build out a real-time pipeline.
So the data from Kafka gets injected into ElasticSearch,
which act as the persistent layer.

And for visualization that's
what the analyst is going to use.

- We're going to use Kibana and Grafana.
- I've noticed that you're using a lot of

- Open Source software here, why is that?
- Open source, there were two reasons,

one is the comfort,
the developers have with the tool,

and second is the customizability
and the flexibility these tools offer.

When I was using the app, one of the things I really liked
was different ways I can actually interact.

And one of those ways
is I could actually upload photos,

let's dig into how you manage
that large image repository.

Sure, let's say you're talking to a doctor,
a dermatologist in this case and you have a skin rash.

So in the app you take a photo
of your skin and uploaded it to S3 bucket.

Right, so once the images
uploaded to an S3 bucket,
so it kicks in the image Rekognition algorithm,

where we tried to determine
whether this is medically relevant or not.

- So why actually filtering the images?
- We want to ensure that the doctors

in our platform do not get
inappropriate images from the users.
And Rekognition is automatically trained

to be able to remove potentially
unsafe images in the repository.
Yes, when we checked it on our dataset,

we found that we didn't have
to retrain the model

because Rekognition did a very good job
of classifying the images.

Halodoc makes use of multiple
AWS databases services like RDS, and DynamoDB.

This not only helps them match the performance
and latency profiles for their microservices,

but it significantly eases the management
of their increasingly distributed system.

This year, we released
multiple updates to RDS,

including SQL level metrics
for different database engines

and performance insights, support for Graviton2,
EC2 instances delivering upto 52%

price for performance benefits,
and we introduced a nifty new feature, RDS Proxy,

to share database connections,
making it even more efficient and scalable.
For Amazon DynamoDB, we expanded support

for global tables in multiple AWS regions,
and we introduced a new multi-region

asynchronous object replication
solution with Amazon S3.

This is super useful for applications
that can tolerate lost events.

Halodoc are continuously looking at servicing
greater insights to doctors and patients,

which means manipulating data
in different ways to do things like analytics.

As you heard, Redshift, AWS's data warehouse service,
is helping them do just that.

This year, we introduced support for materialized views
and federated querying.

And we announced preview
access for cross database queries,

eliminating the need
for multiple database copies

and simplifying support for multiple
business groups on the same cluster.

And for streaming data,
don't forget we now have managed Kafka service,

which can stream data directly into Amazon Redshift.
Now let's go back to the video one more time.

Healthcare is not a single product,
but a series of interactions between patients,

doctors, pharmacists, and drivers.
This is all previously done by hand.

Halodoc had to create
all the connecting tissue to make it work.
Abhilash, 5 million users in just three years,

you're changing the face of healthcare in this country.
But I'm curious to understand what were some of the challenges

- that you had to overcome along the way?
- When we started out, started building

technical solutions for a business problems,
we kind of had to challenge a lot of assumptions.

When we launched the ability to talk to a doctor online,
we kind of assumed that the data

connectivity would be solved for us,
but when we actually launched,

we were seeing significant
error rates up to 20%.

But then we moved our stacks to cloud,
and to the and curity protocol,

- after that we saw a significant success.
- What are some of the other interesting areas

- that you want to take your product into?
- Technically, two areas we are focusing on

is on Containerization and Kubernetes.
And a lot of Investments around AI/ML because we believe
it's going to empower the whole ecosystem.

We want to kind of personalized
our app and website to who the user is,
to give one example, we have health content.

We don't want the same
how contents to be served to all users,

for example if you're a diabetic,
we want to service diabetes content for you,

- and be believed we can achieve that using AI/ML.
- What's the future for Halodoc?

At Halodoc, we believe that we can use the power
of technology to change healthcare in Indonesia.

We're working with Bill
and Melinda Gates Foundation.
We have about 40,000 midwives on the platform

We are building a technology solutions to better
and able midwives to give infant care in rural areas.

That's fantastic. A big vision not just for Halodoc,
but also for this great country.

Abhilash, thank you so much for letting me share
this day with your team and also with yourself.
Thanks a lot.

I've learned a lot here in the last couple of days
and the citizens of Indonesia are learning too.

What's access to healthcare
in rural areas so difficult to access,

and with busy cities like this,
Indonesians now have an option.

Halodoc is changing things
with convenience and time savings.
So, if people did more of this,

they can avoid a lot of that,
saving lives in the process.

As you heard from Abhilash,
a natural progression for Halodocs architecture

is to move those persistent microservices into EKS,
or Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service.

AWS continues to be the best place
to run your container workloads,

with heaps of new enhancements
announced it this year.

For EKS, we started the year with a 50% price reduction.
And we followed up with features like

envelope encryption support
with AWS Key Management Services,

also new EC2 instance types like the Arm
and Inf1 processes,

great for machine learning use cases,
and made it available in multiple

European and APsia-pacific regions.
For Amazon ECS and Fargate,

we introduced a new tool, AWS Copilot.
This CLI allows you to develop, release and

operate containers to create service patterns
for your infrastructure.

And once up and running you can
easily add more services like S3 and databases,

and use it to deploy it
in multiple AWS regions or accounts.

Very handy for growing
and globally available applications.

today's applications in the cloud.
